{{Other uses|Hypersonic (disambiguation)}} {{multiple issues| {{one source|date=October 2014}} {{no footnotes|date=January 2013}} }} [[File:X-43A (Hyper - X) Mach 7 computational fluid dynamic (CFD).jpg|thumb|200px|[[Computational fluid dynamics|CFD]] image of the [[NASA X-43|NASA X-43A]] at Mach 7]] [[File:Dopplereffectsourcemovingrightatmach5.0.gif|thumb|Simulation of hypersonic speed (Mach 5)]] In [[aerodynamics]], a '''hypersonic speed''' is one that greatly exceeds the [[speed of sound]], particularly [[speed of sound|Mach]] 5 and above.{{cite book | title=Atmospheric Flight in the Twentieth Century | editor=Galison, P.; Roland, A. | publisher=Springer | year=2000 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qfrOBgAAQBAJ | isbn=978-94-011-4379-0 | page=90}} The precise [[Mach number]] at which a craft can be said to be flying at hypersonic speed varies, since individual physical changes in the airflow (like molecular [[Dissociation (chemistry)|dissociation]] and [[ionization]]) occur at different speeds; these effects collectively become important around Mach 5. The hypersonic regime is often alternatively defined as speeds where [[ramjet]]s do not produce net [[thrust]]. ==Characteristics of flow== While the definition of hypersonic flow can be quite vague and is generally debatable (especially due to the absence of discontinuity between supersonic and hypersonic flows), a hypersonic flow may be characterized by certain physical phenomena that can no longer be analytically discounted as in supersonic flow. The peculiarity in hypersonic flows are as follows: # Shock layer # [[Aerodynamic heating]] # Entropy layer # Real gas effects # Low density effects # Independence of aerodynamic coefficients with Mach number. ===Small shock stand-off distance=== As a body's Mach number increases, the density behind a [[Shock wave#Bow shocks|bow shock]] generated by the body also increases, which corresponds to a decrease in volume behind the shock due to [[conservation of mass]]. Consequently, the distance between the bow shock and the body decreases at higher Mach numbers. ===Entropy layer=== As Mach numbers increase, the [[entropy]] change across the shock also increases, which results in a strong [[entropy gradient]] and highly [[vortical]] flow that mixes with the [[boundary layer]]. ===Viscous interaction=== A portion of the large [[kinetic energy]] associated with flow at high Mach numbers transforms into [[internal energy]] in the fluid due to viscous effects. The increase in internal energy is realized as an increase in temperature. Since the pressure gradient normal to the flow within a boundary layer is approximately zero for low to moderate hypersonic Mach numbers, the increase of temperature through the boundary layer coincides with a decrease in density. This causes the bottom of the boundary layer to expand, so that the boundary layer over the body grows thicker and can often merge with the shock wave near the body leading edge. ===High-temperature flow=== High temperatures due to a manifestation of viscous dissipation cause non-equilibrium chemical flow properties such as vibrational excitation and [[dissociation (chemistry)|dissociation]] and [[ionization]] of molecules resulting in [[convection|convective]] and [[Atmospheric reentry#Real (non-equilibrium) gas model|radiative heat-flux]]. == Classification of Mach regimes == Although "subsonic" and "supersonic" usually refer to speeds below and above the local [[speed of sound]] respectively, aerodynamicists often use these terms to refer to particular ranges of Mach values. This occurs because a "[[transonic]] regime" exists around M=1 where approximations of the [[Navier–Stokes equations]] used for subsonic design no longer apply, partly because the flow locally exceeds M=1 even when the freestream{{clarify|date=March 2018}} Mach number is below this value. The "supersonic regime" usually refers to the set of Mach numbers for which linearised theory may be used; for example, where the ([[air]]) flow is not chemically reacting and where [[heat transfer]] between air and vehicle may be reasonably neglected in calculations. Generally, [[NASA]] defines "high" hypersonic as any Mach number from 10 to 25, and re-entry speeds as anything greater than Mach 25. Among the aircraft operating in this regime are the [[Space Shuttle]] and (theoretically) various developing [[spaceplane]]s. In the following table, the "regimes" or "ranges of Mach values" are referenced instead of the usual meanings of "subsonic" and "supersonic". {| class="wikitable" |- ! Regime ! (Mach number) ! (mph) ! (km/h) ! (m/s) ! General plane characteristics |- ! style="background-color: #FFFFFF;" | [[Speed of sound|Subsonic]] | <0.8 | <614 | <988 | <274 | Most often propeller-driven and commercial [[turbofan]] aircraft with high aspect-ratio (slender) wings, and rounded features like the nose and leading edges. |- ! style="background-color: #FFC0C0;" | [[Transonic]] | 0.8–1.2 | 614–921 | 988–1,482 | 274–412 | Transonic aircraft nearly always have [[swept wing]]s that delay drag-divergence, and often feature designs adhering to the principles of the Whitcomb [[area rule]]. |- ! style="background-color: #FF8181;" | [[Supersonic]] | 1.2–5.0 | 921–3,836 | 1,482–6,174 | 412–1,715 | Aircraft designed to fly at supersonic speeds show large differences in their aerodynamic design because of the radical differences in the behaviour of [[fluid flow]]s above Mach 1. Sharp edges, thin [[airfoil]]-sections, and all-moving [[tailplane]]/[[canard (aeronautics)|canards]] are common. Modern [[combat aircraft]] must compromise in order to maintain low-speed handling; "true" supersonic designs include the [[F-104 Starfighter]] and BAC/Aérospatiale [[Concorde]]. |- ! style="background-color: #FF4242;" | Hypersonic | 5.0–10.0 | 3,836–7,673 | 6,174–12,348 | 1,715–3,430 | Cooled [[nickel]] or [[titanium]] skin; highly integrated (due to domination of interference effects: non-linear behaviour means that [[Superposition principle|superposition]] of results for separate components is invalid){{clarify|date=March 2018}}, small wings, see [[Boeing X-51|X-51A Waverider]], [[HyperSoar]] and [[WU-14]] (DF-ZF). |- ! style="background-color: #FF0303;" | High-hypersonic | 10.0–25.0 | 7,673–19,182 | 12,348–30,870 | 3,430–8,575 | Thermal control becomes a dominant design consideration. Structure must either be designed to operate hot, or be protected by special [[silicate]] tiles or similar. Chemically reacting flow can also cause corrosion of the vehicle's skin, with free-atomic [[oxygen]] featuring in very high-speed flows. Examples include the [[53T6|53T6 ''ABM-3 Gazelle'']] (Mach 17) anti-ballistic missile, the [[DF-41]] (Mach 25) intercontinental ballistic missile and the Russian [[Avangard (hypersonic glide vehicle) | Avangard]] hypersonic vehicle (Mach 20). Hypersonic designs are often forced into [[Atmospheric entry#Blunt body entry vehicles|blunt configurations]] because of the [[aerodynamic heating]] rising with a reduced [[Radius of curvature (mathematics)|radius of curvature]]. |- ! style="background-color: #C00000;" | Re-entry
speeds | >25.0 | >19,181.7 | >30,869.95 | >8,575 | Ablative heat shield; small or no wings; blunt shape. |} ==Similarity parameters== The categorization of airflow relies on a number of [[Dimensionless numbers|similarity parameters]], which allow the simplification of a nearly infinite number of test cases into groups of similarity. For transonic and [[compressible flow]], the [[Mach number|Mach]] and [[Reynolds number]]s alone allow good categorization of many flow cases. Hypersonic flows, however, require other similarity parameters. First, the [[analytic equation]]s for the [[shock wave|oblique shock angle]] become nearly independent of Mach number at high (~>10) Mach numbers. Second, the formation of strong shocks around aerodynamic bodies means that the freestream [[Reynolds number]] is less useful as an estimate of the behavior of the [[boundary layer]] over a body (although it is still important). Finally, the increased temperature of hypersonic flows mean that [[real gas]] effects become important. For this reason, research in hypersonics is often referred to as [[aerothermodynamics]], rather than [[aerodynamics]]. The introduction of real gas effects means that more variables are required to describe the full state of a gas. Whereas a stationary gas can be described by three variables ([[pressure]], [[temperature]], [[adiabatic index]]), and a moving gas by four ([[flow velocity]]), a hot gas in chemical equilibrium also requires state equations for the chemical components of the gas, and a gas in nonequilibrium solves those state equations using time as an extra variable. This means that for a nonequilibrium flow, something between 10 and 100 variables may be required to describe the state of the gas at any given time. Additionally, rarefied hypersonic flows (usually defined as those with a [[Knudsen number]] above 0.1) do not follow the [[Navier–Stokes equations]]. Hypersonic flows are typically categorized by their total energy, expressed as total [[enthalpy]] (MJ/kg), total pressure (kPa-MPa), stagnation pressure (kPa-MPa), [[stagnation temperature]] (K), or flow velocity (km/s). [[Wallace D. Hayes]] developed a similarity parameter, similar to the [[area rule|Whitcomb area rule]], which allowed similar configurations to be compared. ==Regimes== Hypersonic flow can be approximately separated into a number of regimes. The selection of these regimes is rough, due to the blurring of the boundaries where a particular effect can be found. ===Perfect gas=== In this regime, the gas can be regarded as an [[ideal gas]]. Flow in this regime is still Mach number dependent. Simulations start to depend on the use of a constant-temperature wall, rather than the adiabatic wall typically used at lower speeds. The lower border of this region is around Mach 5, where [[ramjet]]s become inefficient, and the upper border around Mach 10-12. ===Two-temperature ideal gas=== This is a subset of the perfect gas regime, where the gas can be considered chemically perfect, but the rotational and vibrational temperatures of the gas must be considered separately, leading to two temperature models. See particularly the modeling of supersonic nozzles, where vibrational freezing becomes important. ===Dissociated gas=== In this regime, diatomic or polyatomic gases (the gases found in most atmospheres) begin to [[dissociation (chemistry)|dissociate]] as they come into contact with the [[Shock wave|bow shock]] generated by the body. [[catalysis|Surface catalysis]] plays a role in the calculation of surface heating, meaning that the type of surface material also has an effect on the flow. The lower border of this regime is where any component of a gas mixture first begins to dissociate in the stagnation point of a flow (which for nitrogen is around 2000 K). At the upper border of this regime, the effects of [[ionization]] start to have an effect on the flow. ===Ionized gas=== In this regime the [[ionization|ionized]] electron population of the stagnated flow becomes significant, and the electrons must be modeled separately. Often the electron temperature is handled separately from the temperature of the remaining gas components. This region occurs for freestream flow velocities around 10–12 km/s. Gases in this region are modeled as non-radiating [[Plasma (physics)|plasmas]]. ===Radiation-dominated regime=== Above around 12 km/s, the heat transfer to a vehicle changes from being conductively dominated to radiatively dominated. The modeling of gases in this regime is split into two classes: #[[Optical depth|Optically thin]]: where the gas does not re-absorb radiation emitted from other parts of the gas #Optically thick: where the radiation must be considered a separate source of energy. The modeling of optically thick gases is extremely difficult, since, due to the calculation of the radiation at each point, the computation load theoretically expands exponentially as the number of points considered increases. ==See also== {{colbegin}} *[[Supersonic transport]] *[[Lifting body]] *[[Atmospheric entry]] *[[Hypersonic flight]] *[[DARPA Falcon Project]] *[[Reaction Engines Skylon]] (design study) *[[Reaction Engines A2]] (design study) *[[HyperSoar]] (concept) *[[WaveRider|X-51 A Waverider]] *[[X-20 Dyna-Soar]] (cancelled) *[[Rockwell X-30]] (cancelled) *[[Avatar (spacecraft)|Avatar RLV]] (2001 Indian concept study) *[[Hypersonic Technology Demonstrator Vehicle]] (Indian project) *[[Ayaks]] (Russian, from 1990's) *[[WU-14|WU-14 Hypersonic Glide Vehicle]] (Under Development) *[[Lockheed Martin SR-72]] (Planned) {{colend}} ;Engines *[[Rocket engine]] *[[Ramjet]] *[[Scramjet]] *[[Reaction Engines SABRE]], [[LAPCAT]] (design studies) ;Missiles *[[Shaurya (missile)]] Ballistic Missile - {{flagicon|India}} [[India]] (Entered Production) *[[BrahMos-II]] Cruise Missile - {{flagicon|India}} {{flagicon|Russia}} (Under Development) *[[9K720 Iskander]] Short-range ballistic missile {{flagicon|Russia}} [[Russia]] (Currently In Service) ;Other flow regimes * [[Subsonic flight]] * [[Transonic]] * [[Supersonic speed]] ==References== {{refbegin}} * {{cite book|last=Anderson|first=John|year=2006|title=Hypersonic and High-Temperature Gas Dynamics Second Edition|publisher=AIAA Education Series|isbn=1-56347-780-7}} {{refend}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Hypersonics}} *[http://www.grc.nasa.gov/WWW/BGH/index.html NASA's Guide to Hypersonics] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20121011210111/http://www3.imperial.ac.uk/hypersonics Hypersonics Group at Imperial College] *[http://www.mech.uq.edu.au/hyper/ University of Queensland Centre for Hypersonics] *[http://seit.unsw.adfa.edu.au/research/activity.php?activity_id=42 High Speed Flow Group at University of New South Wales] *[http://www.eng.ox.ac.uk/thermofluids/research/hypersonics-research-group Hypersonics Group at the University of Oxford] {{DEFAULTSORT:Hypersonic Speed}} [[Category:Aerodynamics]] [[Category:Aerospace engineering]] [[Category:Airspeed]] [[Category:Spacecraft propulsion]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = IEEE Smart Grid | logo = [[File:IEEESmartGrid logo.jpg]] | type = [[Professional organization|Professional Organization]] | founded_date = January 2010 | location = [[Piscataway Township, New Jersey|Piscataway]], [[New jersey|New Jersey]] | origins = Global initiative launched by [[IEEE]] | key_people = Wanda Reder, IEEE Smart Grid [[Chairman|Chair]]
[[Massoud Amin]], IEEE Smart Grid Newsletter Chair
J. Roberto de Marco, IEEE Smart Grid World Forum Steering Committee Chair | area_served = Worldwide | focus = [[Smart grid|Smart Grid]], [[Electric power transmission|Power Transmission]] and [[Electricity distribution|Distribution]], [[Renewable energy|Renewable Energy]], [[Smart grid#Integrated communications|Communications]], [[Electric vehicle|Electric Vehicles]] | method = Industry standards, Conferences, Publications | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = | homepage = {{URL|http://smartgrid.ieee.org}} | tax_exempt = | dissolved = | footnotes = }} '''IEEE Smart Grid''' is an initiative launched by [[Ieee|IEEE]] to help provide expertise and guidance for individuals and organizations involved in the modernization and optimization of the power grid, better known as the "[[smart grid]]". IEEE Smart Grid encompasses an array of activities, including development of new smart grid-related [[International standard|standards]], best practices, publications, and conferences and educational opportunities.{{cite web |url=http://smartgrid.ieee.org/ieee-smart-grid |title= IEEE & Smart Grid |publisher=IEEE Smart Grid |accessdate=October 25, 2011}} == History == IEEE's involvement in the emerging smart grid reaches back to its development of power and energy standards.{{cite web | url=http://standards.ieee.org/findstds/standard/power_and_energy.html | title=Power and Energy Standards | author=IEEE Standards Association | publisher=IEEE | accessdate=December 7, 2011}} In 2007, the [[Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007|Energy Independence and Security Act]] (EISA) was signed into law by President [[George W. Bush]]. EISA directed that under the auspices of the [[US DOE|US Department of Energy]] (US DOE), the [[Nist|National Institute of Standards and Technology]] (NIST) be tasked with the development of a framework including protocols and model standards for information management to achieve interoperability of smart grid devices and systems. In Title XIII, Section 1305(a)(2) of EISA, IEEE was named as one of the [[Standards Setting Organization|Standard Setting Organizations]] (SSOs) whose work would be vital in the development of standards for NIST's [[Smart grid policy in the United States#SECTION 1305. SMART GRID INTEROPERABILITY FRAMEWORK.|Smart Grid Interoperability Framework]].Updegrove, Andrew. [http://www.consortiuminfo.org/bulletins/apr09.php#feature, Standards and the Smart Grid: The U.S. Experience], ''Standards Today'', Vol VIII No 3, April - May, 2009. As part of the first phase of NIST's Smart Grid Interoperability Framework, 16 initial standards were offered for adoption, including three developed by IEEE: [[C37.118#Standards|C37.118]], [[IEEE 1547]], and IEEE 1686-2007. In May 2009, IEEE announced the launch of a new smart grid effort targeted to the power engineering, communications, and information technology disciplines. The first project in this effort, titled "The IEEE Standard 2030 Guide for Smart Grid Interoperability of Energy Technology and Information Technology Operation with the Electric Power System (EPS) and End-Use Applications and Loads" ([[IEEE P2030|IEEE 2030]]) established a knowledge framework for understanding and defining smart grid interoperability of the electric power system with end use applications, setting the stage for future smart grid-related standards.{{cite press |url=http://www.ieee.org/documents/smart_grid_leadership_press_release.pdf |title=IEEE Provides Leadership for Smart Grid Initiative Around the Globe |publisher=IEEE |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |date=June 1, 2009}} In January 2010, IEEE launched the first phase of IEEE Smart Grid, a new global initiative designed to bring together the organization's broad array of resources to provide expertise and guidance for those involved in Smart Grid worldwide.{{cite press |url=http://smartgrid.ieee.org/resources/ieee-press-releases/198-ieee-launches-smart-grid-web-portal-content-rich-gateway-providing-intelligence-education-and-news-on-global-smart-grid |title=IEEE Launches Smart Grid Web Portal, Content-Rich Gateway Providing Intelligence, Education, and News on Global Smart Grid |publisher=IEEE |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |date=January 19, 2010}} Later that year, IEEE published inaugural editions of two new publications, cross-discipline archival journals entitled ''IEEE Transactions on Smart Grid'',{{cite web | url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/RecentIssue.jsp?punumber=5165411 | title=IEEE Transactions on Smart Grid | author=IEEE | publisher=IEEE | date=June 2010 | accessdate=December 10, 2011}} and ''IEEE Transactions on Sustainable Energy''.{{cite web | url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/RecentIssue.jsp?punumber=5165391 | title=IEEE Transactions on Sustainable Energy | author=IEEE | publisher=IEEE | date=June 2010 | accessdate=December 10, 2011}} == Current work == IEEE's approach to the smart grid is to view it as a large "System of Systems" wherein individual smart grid domains based on the NIST Smart Grid Conceptual Model are expanded into three layers: Power and Energy, Communications, and IT/Computer. IEEE considers the Communications and IT/Computer layers to be enabling infrastructure for the Power and Energy layer.{{cite web | url=http://smartgrid.ieee.org/ieee-smart-grid/smart-grid-conceptual-model | title=Smart Grid Conceptual Model | author=IEEE | publisher=IEEE | accessdate=December 10, 2011}} === IEEE Smart Grid Portal === As part of the first phase of IEEE Smart Grid, IEEE unveiled the IEEE Smart Grid Portal in January 2010. As originally designed, the site served as an online clearinghouse providing smart grid-focused news, information, commentary, videos, and event information for a broad audience including business and industry, academic, and government users, as well as consumers. The portal is also home to the initiative's monthly digest, the ''IEEE Smart Grid Newsletter''.Amin, Massoud. [http://smartgrid.ieee.org/newsletter/january-2011/68-welcome-to-the-ieee-smart-grid-newsletter, Welcome to the IEEE Smart Grid Newsletter], ''IEEE Smart Grid Newsletter'', January 2011. The IEEE Smart Grid Portal was relaunched in September 2011. The redesigned site included improved search capabilities and other new features, such as a broader selection of video interviews and Q&A's with industry experts, business leaders, and researchers. It also facilitated greater user access to approved and in-development IEEE smart grid standards and an expanded conference calendar.{{cite press release |title=IEEE Unveils Newly Redesigned Content-Rich Smart Grid Web Portal; Gateway To IEEE Thought Leaders' Insights |url=http://smartgrid.ieee.org/resources/ieee-press-releases/410-ieee-unveils-newly-redesigned-content-rich-smart-grid-web-portal-gateway-to-ieee-thought-leaders-insights |publisher=IEEE Smart Grid |date=September 27, 2011 |accessdate=December 6, 2011}} === Standards === IEEE continues to work closely with NIST on its standards roadmap and conformance testing/certification framework{{cite press release |title=Draft NIST Framework and Roadmap for Smart Grid Interoperability Standards, Release 2.0 |url=http://collaborate.nist.gov/twiki-sggrid/pub/SmartGrid/IKBFramework/Draft_NIST_Framework_Release_2-0_10-17-2011.pdf |publisher=National Institute of Standards and Technology |date=October 17, 2011 |accessdate=December 6, 2011}} for the smart grid. The organization also collaborates with other global standards bodies to effectively facilitate standards coordination and to ensure the intensifying smart grid movement’s success. There are more than 100 standards that have been approved{{cite web|url=http://smartgrid.ieee.org/standards/approved-ieee-smart-grid-standards|title=Approved IEEE Smart Grid Standards |publisher=IEEE Smart Grid |accessdate=October 26, 2011}} or in development{{cite web|url=http://smartgrid.ieee.org/standards/proposed-standards-related-to-smart-grid|title=Proposed Standards Related to Smart Grid |publisher=IEEE Smart Grid |accessdate=October 26, 2011}} relating to the smart grid. Among the broad number of systems and technologies addressed by these standards are [[Broadband over Power Lines#Broadband over power line .28BPL.29|broadband over power line]], [[cyber security]], [[Distributed Energy Resources|distributed energy resources]], [[DNP3|Distributed Network Protocol]] (DNP3), and [[Greenhouse gas]] [[emissions credit]]s, among others. ====Sampling of Approved IEEE Smart Grid Standards==== * IEEE 1547-2003 Standard for Interconnecting Distributed Resources with Electric Power Systems{{cite web|url=http://standards.ieee.org/findstds/standard/1547-2003.html |title=1547-2003 - IEEE Standard for Interconnecting Distributed Resources with Electric Power Systems |publisher=IEEE Standards Association |accessdate=December 7, 2011}} * IEEE 1675-2008 Standard for Broadband over Power Line Hardware{{cite web|url=http://standards.ieee.org/findstds/standard/1675-2008.html |title=1675-2008 - IEEE Standard for Broadband Over Powerline Hardware |publisher=IEEE Standards Association |accessdate=December 7, 2011}} * IEEE 1686-2007 Standard for Substation Intelligent Electronic Devices (IEDs) Cyber Security Capabilities{{cite web|url=http://standards.ieee.org/findstds/standard/1686-2007.html |title=1686-2007 - IEEE Standard for Substation Intelligent Electronic Devices (IEDs) Cyber Security Capabilities |publisher=IEEE Standards Association |accessdate=December 7, 2011}} * IEEE 1815-2010 Standard for Electric Power Systems Communications—Distributed Network Protocol (DNP3){{cite web|url=http://standards.ieee.org/findstds/standard/1815-2010.html |title=1815-2010 - IEEE Standard for Electric Power Systems Communications -- Distributed Network Protocol (DNP3) |publisher=IEEE Standards Association |accessdate=December 7, 2011}} * IEEE 2030-2011 Guide for Smart Grid Interoperability of Energy Technology and Information Technology Operation with the Electric Power System (EPS), End-Use Applications, and Loads{{cite web|url=http://standards.ieee.org/findstds/standard/2030-2011.html |title=2030-2011 - IEEE Guide for Smart Grid Interoperability of Energy Technology and Information Technology Operation with the Electric Power System (EPS), End-Use Applications, and Loads |publisher=IEEE Standards Association |accessdate=December 7, 2011}} ====Sampling of Proposed IEEE Smart Grid Standards==== * IEEE P1377 Draft Standard for Utility Industry Metering Communication Protocol Application Layer (End Device Data Tables){{cite web|url=http://standards.ieee.org/develop/project/1377.html |title=P1377 - IEEE Draft Standard for Utility Industry Metering Communication Protocol Application Layer (End Device Data Tables) |publisher=IEEE Standards Association |accessdate=December 8, 2011}} * IEEE P1547.6 Draft Recommended Practice For Interconnecting Distributed Resources With Electric Power Systems Distribution Secondary Networks{{cite web|url=http://standards.ieee.org/findstds/standard/1547.6-2011.html |title=1547.6-2011 - IEEE Recommended Practice for Interconnecting Distributed Resources with Electric Power Systems Distribution Secondary Networks |accessdate=December 8, 2011}} * IEEE P1595 Draft Standard for Quantifying Greenhouse Gas Emission Credits from Small Hydro and Wind Power Projects, and for Grid Baseline Conditions{{cite web|url=http://standards.ieee.org/develop/project/1595.html |title=P1595 - Standard for Designating and Quantifying Green Energy Projects in the Electricity Sector |publisher=IEEE Standards Association |accessdate=December 8, 2011}} * IEEE P1613 Draft Standard Environmental and Testing Requirements for Communications Networking Devices Installed in Electric Power Substations{{cite web|url=http://standards.ieee.org/develop/project/1613.html |title=P1613 - Standard for Environmental and Testing Requirements for Communications Networking Devices Installed in Electric Power Facilities |publisher=IEEE Standards Association |accessdate=December 8, 2011}} * IEEE P1797 Draft Guide for Design and Application of Solar Technology in Commercial Power Generating Stations{{cite web|url=http://standards.ieee.org/develop/project/1797.html |title=P1797 - Guide for Design and Application of Solar Technology in Commercial Power Generating Stations |publisher=IEEE Standards Association |accessdate=December 8, 2011}} === Events === IEEE Smart Grid and its participating societies sponsor and host major conferences, symposiums, and other events on a global basis.{{cite web|url= http://smartgrid.ieee.org/conferences |title=IEEE Smart Grid Conferences |publisher=IEEE Smart Grid |accessdate=November 21, 2011}} Dedicated to providing a forum for the sharing of ideas and information about smart grid concepts, deployments, and technology advancements, IEEE Smart Grid events generally span several days in length and attract attendees from around the world. Conference programs often consist of educational tracks with keynote speeches, panel discussions, and roundtables led by industry notables, researchers, engineers, academics, policymakers, and other key stakeholders. Among IEEE Smart Grid flagship events are its Innovative Smart Grid Technologies (ISGT) Conference,{{cite press |url=http://smartgrid.ieee.org/resources/ieee-press-releases/178-ieee-innovative-smart-grid-technologies-isgt-2011-conference-summary |title=IEEE Innovative Smart Grid Technologies (ISGT) 2011 Conference Summary |publisher=IEEE |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |date=January 2009}} SmartGridComm,{{cite web|url=http://www.ieee-smartgridcomm.org |title=IEEE SmartGridComm |publisher=IEEE Communications Society |accessdate=November 21, 2011}} and Smart Grid World Forum.{{cite web|url=http://www.ieee-smartgridworld.org |title=IEEE Smart Grid World Forum |publisher=IEEE Smart Grid |accessdate=December 8, 2011}} Other recent major IEEE Smart Grid events include: ==== 2010 ==== * Asia-Pacific Power & Energy Engineering Conference (APPEEC) 2010, sponsored by the IEEE Power & Energy Society and centered on best practices in power generation, transmission, and distribution, and conventional and renewable energy{{cite web|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/mostRecentIssue.jsp?punumber=5447158 |title=APPEEC 2010 |publisher=IEEE Power & Energy Society |accessdate=2016-02-28}} * International Symposium on Power Line Communications and its Applications (ISPLC) 2010, designed to stimulate discussions on electrical power distribution wires as a viable communication channel{{cite web|url=http://ewh.ieee.org/conf/isplc/2010 |title=ISPLC 2010 |publisher=IEEE Communications Society |accessdate=November 21, 2011}} * Conference On Innovative Technologies For An Efficient & Reliable Electricity Supply (ITERES) 2010, focused on examining the development of components for and planning and implementing of the new Smart/Resilient Electric Grid and integration of the various existing and alternative/renewable electric power system components{{cite web|url=http://www.ieee-energy.org/ |title=ITERES 2010 |publisher=IEEE |accessdate=November 21, 2011}} ==== 2011 ==== * Power Systems Conference & Exhibition (PSCE) 2011, a plenary session dedicated to presenting power system tutorials and discussing the theme "The Next Generation Grid – Putting It All Together"{{cite web|url=http://www.pscexpo.com |title=IEEE IPSCE 2011 |publisher=IEEE Power & Energy Society |accessdate=November 21, 2011}} * IEEE Technology Time Machine (TTM) 2011, a high level thought leadership conference about revolutionary technology platforms that will change lives during the next decade{{cite web|url=http://www.techbeyond2020.ust.hk |title=IEEE Technology Time Machine 2011 |publisher=IEEE |accessdate=November 21, 2011}} * PowerTech 2011, IEEE Power & Energy Society Europe's anchor conference, offering a platform for electric power engineering scientists and engineers to share knowledge, ideas, and results of scientific work{{cite web|url=http://ewh.ieee.org/conf/powertech/2011 |title=IEEE PES Trondheim PowerTech 2011 |publisher=IEEE Power & Energy Society |accessdate=November 21, 2011}} IEEE Smart Grid is also home to smaller workshops, sessions, and continuing education courses, like the IEEE PES "Plain Talk About the Electric Power System" series,{{cite web|url=http://www.ieee-pes.org/education/programs/plain-talk-courses |title=Plain Talk About the Electric Power System |publisher=IEEE Power & Energy Society |accessdate=December 7, 2011}} which are hosted by various societies and their chapters. === Publications === Through its Smart Grid Initiative, societies, working groups, committees and sub-committees, IEEE has published nearly 5,000 papers, manuscripts, guides, and other documents relating to the smart grid,{{cite web |url=http://smartgrid.ieee.org/search?searchword=smart+grid&category=publications |title=IEEE Publications Search |publisher=IEEE |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120508010242/http://smartgrid.ieee.org/search?searchword=smart+grid&category=publications |archivedate=May 8, 2012 |df= }} including: ====IEEE Smart Grid Newsletter==== In January 2011, IEEE unveiled the ''IEEE Smart Grid Newsletter'',{{cite web|url=http://smartgrid.ieee.org/newsletter/january-2011 |title=IEEE Smart Grid Newsletter - January 2011 |publisher=IEEE Smart Grid |accessdate=January 25, 2012}} a monthly electronic digest. The publication's content focuses on practical and technical information, as well as commentary and opinion on emerging smart grid technologies, new standards, global deployments, and other smart grid-related subject matter. Contributors include industry leaders, prominent researchers and academics, and advocates and policy experts. Dr. S. Massoud Amin, Director and [[Honeywell#Sweatt leadership legacy|Honeywell/H.W. Sweatt]] Chair, Technological Leadership Institute, and Professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering, [[University Of Minnesota|University of Minnesota]], is the publication's Chairman, and William Sweet, Emeritus News Editor, [[Ieee spectrum|IEEE Spectrum]], is its Managing Editor. ====IEEE Transactions on Smart Grid==== Intended to disseminate smart grid research results on energy generation, transmission, distribution and delivery, ''IEEE Transactions on Smart Grid'' offers original research on smart grid theories, technologies, design, policies, and implementation. It also accepts manuscripts on smart grid design and implementation, and evaluation of energy systems involving smart grid technologies and applications. Published quarterly, ''IEEE Transactions on Smart Grid'' is jointly produced by multiple IEEE societies, including its [[IEEE Computational Intelligence Society|Computational Intelligence Society]], [[IEEE Communications Society|Communications Society]], [[IEEE Computer Society|Computer Society]], [[IEEE Control Systems Society|Control Systems Society]], [[IEEE Industry Applications Society|Industry Applications Society]], [[IEEE Industrial Electronics Society|Industrial Electronics Society]], [[IEEE Instrumentation & Measurement Society|Instrumentation and Measurement Society]], [[IEEE Power Electronics Society|Power Electronics Society]], [[IEEE Power & Energy Society|Power & Energy Society]], and [[IEEE Signal Processing Society|Signal Processing Society]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ieee-pes.org/ieee-transactions-on-smart-grid |title=IEEE Transactions on Smart Grid |publisher=IEEE |accessdate=December 6, 2011}} In August 2011, the journal's "Protecting Smart Grid Automation Systems Against Cyberattacks," authored by IEEE members Dong Wei and Yan Lu became the three millionth document in [[IEEE Xplore]], IEEE's extensive digital library.{{cite press release |title=IEEE Xplore® Digital Library Reaches Three Million Documents |url=http://smartgrid.ieee.org/resources/ieee-press-releases/207-ieee-xplore-digital-library-reaches-three-million-documents |publisher=IEEE |date=August 31, 2011 |accessdate=December 6, 2011}} Mohammad Shahidehpour is the current Editor-in-Chief of ''IEEE Transactions on Smart Grid''. ==== IEEE Transactions on Sustainable Energy ==== A quarterly, cross-discipline journal featuring original research, ''IEEE Transactions on Sustainable Energy'' focuses on sustainable energy generation, transmission, distribution and delivery. Manuscripts concentrating on sustainable energy power systems design, implementation, and evaluations, as well as surveys of existing work are also accepted for consideration. Launched in April 2010, ''IEEE Transactions on Sustainable Energy'' is jointly published by IEEE's Industry Applications Society, Industrial Electronics Society, Instrumentation and Measurement Society, [[IEEE Oceanic Engineering Society]], Power Electronics Society, Power & Energy Society, [[IEEE Photonics Society|Photonics Society]], and the [[IEEE Society on Social Implications of Technology|Society on Social Implications of Technology]]. The journal's current Editor-in-Chief is Saifur Rahman, Joseph Loring Professor of [[Electrical and computer engineering|ECE]] at [[Virginia Tech|Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University]] (Virginia Tech).{{cite web|url=http://www.ieee-pes.org/ieee-transactions-on-sustainable-energy |title=IEEE Transactions on Sustainable Energy |publisher=IEEE |accessdate=December 6, 2011}} == Participating IEEE societies == IEEE is home to 38 technical Societies encompassing a large array of disciplines and specialized fields of interest such as [[aerospace]] and electronic systems, medicine and biology engineering, [[magnetics]], [[robotics]], and vehicular technology.{{cite web|url=http://www.ieee.org/membership_services/membership/societies/index.html |title=IEEE Society Memberships |publisher=IEEE |accessdate=December 8, 2011}} Many of these societies are engaged in smart grid-related work, however, due to their specific areas of expertise, several have emerged as leaders in smart grid technology development and promotion: ===IEEE Communications Society=== The [[IEEE Communications Society]] (IEEE ComSoc) is an IEEE professional society of more than 8,800 communications industry professionals. As part of its goal to foster original work in all aspects of communications science, engineering, and technology, IEEE ComSoc sponsors a variety of publications, conferences, educational programs, local activities, and technical committees.{{cite web|url=http://www.comsoc.org/about |title=About ComSoc |publisher=ComSoc |accessdate=October 26, 2011}} IEEE ComSoc is a key stakeholder in IEEE Smart Grid, sponsoring a variety of related standards like [[IEEE 1901|IEEE 1901-2010]]{{cite web|url=http://standards.ieee.org/findstds/standard/1901-2010.html |title=1901-2010 - IEEE Standard for Broadband over Power Line Networks: Medium Access Control and Physical Layer Specifications |publisher=IEEE Standards Association |accessdate=December 8, 2011}} and conferences like the IEEE International Symposium on Power Line Communications and its Applications (ISPLC){{cite web|url=http://www.ieee-isplc.org/2011 |title=IEEE International Symposium on Power Line Communications and its Applications |publisher=IEEE Communications Society |accessdate=December 8, 2011}} and SmartGridComm, one of IEEE Smart Grid's flagship events. Along with a number of its sister societies, IEEE ComSoc jointly publishes ''IEEE Transactions on Smart Grid''. ===IEEE Computer Society=== The [[IEEE Computer Society]] is a professional society for computing professionals and researchers based in [[Washington, D.C.|Washington, DC]]. With 85,000 members worldwide, it is the largest IEEE society. The group offers a variety of resources, including certification programs, printed and electronic books and journals, and conferences and events. The IEEE Computer Society is an active participant in IEEE Smart Grid, through the sponsorship of smart grid-applicable standards and practices, like [[IEEE 1471]]{{cite web|url=http://standards.ieee.org/findstds/standard/1471-2000.html |title=1471-2000 - IEEE Recommended Practice for Architectural Description for Software-Intensive Systems |publisher=IEEE Standards Association |accessdate=December 8, 2011}} and [[ISO/IEC 42010|IEEE 42010-2011]],{{cite web|url=http://standards.ieee.org/findstds/standard/42010-2011.html |title=42010-2011 - IEEE Standard for Systems and software engineering --- Architecture description |publisher=IEEE Standards Association |accessdate=December 8, 2011}} and events such as ISGT. It is also one of the publishing societies for ''IEEE Transactions on Smart Grid''. ===IEEE Power & Energy Society=== The [[IEEE Power & Energy Society]] (IEEE PES) is home to 28,000 electric power energy professionals. Among the technical subject matter addressed by IEEE PES are electric power research, as well as system design, installation, and operation. The society aims to ensure the safe, sustainable, economic and reliable conversion, generation, transmission, distribution, storage and usage of electric energy, including its measurement and control. IEEE PES is one of the main proponents of IEEE Smart Grid, sponsoring numerous smart grid-related standards, such as IEEE 487-2007,{{cite web|url=http://standards.ieee.org/findstds/standard/487-2007.html |title=487-2007 - IEEE Recommended Practice for the Protection of Wire-Line Communication Facilities Serving Electric Supply Locations |publisher=IEEE Standards Association |accessdate=December 8, 2011}} IEEE 1138-2009,{{cite web|url=http://standards.ieee.org/findstds/standard/1138-2009.html |title=1138-2009 - IEEE Standard for Testing and Performance for Optical Ground Wire (OPGW) for Use on Electric Utility Power Lines |publisher=IEEE Standards Association |accessdate=December 8, 2011}} IEEE 1222-2003,{{cite web|url=http://standards.ieee.org/findstds/standard/1222-2003.html |title=1222-2003 - IEEE Standard for All-Dielectric Self-Supporting Fiber Optic Cable |publisher=IEEE Standards Association |accessdate=December 8, 2011}} and IEEE 1615-2007.{{cite web|url=http://standards.ieee.org/findstds/standard/1615-2007.html |title=1615-2007 - IEEE Recommended Practice for Network Communication in Electric Power Substations |publisher=IEEE Standards Association |accessdate=December 8, 2011}} The group frequently sponsors smart grid-related events on a national, international, and regional basis, including ISGT, IEEE Power Systems Conference & Exposition (PSCE),{{cite web|url=http://www.pscexpo.com |title=IEEE Power Systems Conference & Exposition |publisher=IEEE Power & Energy Society |accessdate=December 8, 2011}} and the IEEE PES Plain Talk series. ===IEEE Society on Social Implications of Technology=== The [[IEEE Society on Social Implications of Technology]] (SSIT) focuses on the environmental, health, and safety implications of technology. Among the topics addressed by its 2,000 global members are ethics and professional responsibility, the history of [[electrotechnology]], public policy, and technology-related societal issues. IEEE SSIT members are generally professionals from multiple disciplines, including energy, information technology, and telecommunications. The group publishes ''IEEE Technology and Society Magazine'', a quarterly journal.{{cite web|url=http://ieeessit.org/technology_and_society |title=IEEE Technology and Society Magazine |publisher=IEEE Society on Social Implications of Technology |accessdate=December 8, 2011}} IEEE SSIT sponsors or contributes regularly to IEEE Smart Grid standards and events, and is one of the publishing societies of ''IEEE Transactions on Sustainable Energy''. ==Influence and impact== Many of the participating IEEE Smart Grid members have had demonstrable impact on the smart grid ecosystem. Often called upon as smart grid experts by the media, members appear frequently in magazines and newsletters such as ''Electric Energy Online'',Mantooth, Alan. [http://www.electricenergyonline.com/?page=show_article&mag=70&article=570, Beyond Earth-friendly: How renewables will impact the grid], ''Electric Energy Online'', April 2011. ''Electric Light & Power'' magazine,Lefevre, Russell. [http://www.elp.com/index/display/article-display/4741025818/articles/electric-light-power/volume-89/issue-4/sections/smart-grid-needs-energy-efficiency.html, Smart Grid Needs Energy Efficiency], ''Electric Light & Power'', July 1, 2011. and ''FierceSmartGrid'',DeBlasio, Dick. [http://www.fiercesmartgrid.com/story/rushing-smart-grid/2011-11-09#ixzz1dEwwUC2A, Rushing the Smart Grid], ''FierceSmartGrid'', September 9, 2011. as well as on broadcast programs like [[NPR]]'s ''Science Friday''{{cite web|url=http://m.npr.org/news/Technology/137107102 |title=Building A Better Electric Grid |publisher=NPR Science Friday |accessdate=December 7, 2011}} and ''[[blogtalkradio]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.blogtalkradio.com/greenlivingguy/2011/06/30/interview-with-ieee-erich-gunther-on-smart-grid-and-why |title=Interview with IEEE Erich Gunther on Smart Grid and Why?! |publisher=blogtalkradio |accessdate=December 7, 2011}} ''greentechgrid'' unveiled "The Networked Grid 100: Movers and Shakers of the Smart Grid" in February 2010, naming [[IEEE Fellow]], John D. McDonald, as one of their listees.Leeds, David J; Thompson, Rick. [http://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/the-networked-grid-100/, The Networked Grid 100: Movers and Shakers of the Smart Grid], ''greentechgrid'', February 1, 2010. In November 2011, ''FierceEnergy'' magazine announced its inaugural "Power Players -- The 15 Most Influential People in Energy" list,Vergetis Lundin, Barbara. [http://www.fierceenergy.com/slideshow/power-players-15-most-influential-people-energy#ixzz1fyzbjMxl, Power Players -- The 15 Most Influential People in Energy], ''FierceEnergy'', November 19, 2011. which included four IEEE Smart Grid members: IEEE Life Member Dick DeBlasio, IEEE Fellow Erich Gunther, McDonald, and IEEE Computer Society member, Andres Carvallo.{{cite press |url=http://smartgrid.ieee.org/resources/ieee-press-releases/458-multiple-ieee-smart-grid-experts-among-fierceenergys-15-most-influential-people-in-energy |title=Multiple IEEE Smart Grid Experts Among FierceEnergy’s "15 Most Influential People in Energy" |publisher=IEEE Smart Grid |accessdate=December 8, 2011 |date=November 30, 2011}} IEEE Smart Grid members have also had impact in other areas, including public policy. In May 2004, Erich Gunther was appointed by the US DOE as a member of its GridWise Architecture Council (GWAC), and currently serves as its chair.{{cite web|url=http://www.gridwiseac.org/members |title=Current Members |publisher=Gridwise Architecture Council |accessdate=December 7, 2011}} IEEE Smart Grid member, John D. McDonald, was selected as the inaugural member of the US DOE Electric Advisory Committee,{{cite press |url=http://energy.gov/sites/prod/files/oeprod/DocumentsandMedia/Press_Release_EAC_41708.pdf |title=DOE Announces Membership of New Electricity Advisory Committee |publisher=US Department of Energy |accessdate=December 6, 2011|date=April 17, 2008}} which he served on during 2008.{{cite web|url=http://energy.gov/sites/prod/files/oeprod/DocumentsandMedia/Press_Release_EAC_41708.pdf |title=Electricity Advisory Committee 2008 Membership Roster |publisher=US Department of Energy |accessdate=December 8, 2011 |date=October 20, 2008}} He was followed by IEEE Smart Grid Chair, Wanda Reder, who was appointed to the committee in 2010.{{cite web|url=http://energy.gov/sites/prod/files/oeprod/DocumentsandMedia/EAC_Roster_11-9-10.pdf |title=Electricity Advisory Committee 2010 Membership Roster |publisher=US Department of Energy |accessdate=December 8, 2011 |date=November 9, 2010}} On July 1, 2010, McDonald along with Dr. George W. Arnold, National Coordinator for Smart Grid, NIST; Mason W. Emnett, Associate Director of The Office of Energy Policy and Innovation, [[Federal Energy Regulatory Commission]] (FERC); Conrad Eustis, Director of Retail Technology Development, [[Portland General Electric]]; and Lillie Coney, Associate Director, [[Electronic Privacy Information Center]] were called upon to brief the U.S. House of Representatives’ [[United States House Science Subcommittee on Technology and Innovation|Subcommittee on Technology and Innovation]], [[United States House Committee on Science, Space and Technology|House Committee on Science and Technology]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CHRG-111hhrg57602/html/CHRG-111hhrg57602.htm |title=Smart Grid Architecture and Standards: Assessing Coordination and Progress |publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office |accessdate=December 9, 2011 |date=July 1, 2010}} At the hearing entitled "Smart Grid Architecture and Standards: Assessing Coordination and Progress", he provided testimony on the progress of standards for Smart Grid interoperability and cyber security, stating: "Also crucial to this undertaking are developing system architecture and standards that provide the essential foundation for bringing together the electrical and communications infrastructure, and for evolving technology to meet many and disparate needs. Both the IEEE through its Standards Association and NIST have already shown tremendous progress in these areas."Berst, Jesse. [http://www.smartgridnews.com/artman/publish/Technologies_Standards/NIST-IEEE-Brief-House-Subcommittee-on-Progress-in-Smart-Grid-Standards-2639.html, NIST, IEEE Brief House Subcommittee on Progress in Smart Grid Standards], ''Smart Grid News'', July 6, 2010. ==See also== {{Portal|Energy}} * [[Distributed generation|Distributed Generation]] * [[Energy policy|Energy Policy]] * [[Intermittent power sources|Intermittent Power Sources]] * [[Renewables]] * [[Smart grid|Smart Grid]] * [[Smart grids by country|Smart Grids by Country]] * [[Smart meter|Smart Meter]] ==External links== * [http://energy.gov/oe/services/electricity-advisory-committee-eac Electricity Advisory Committee (EAC)] * [http://www.gridwiseac.org GridWise Architecture Council], official web site * [https://www.nist.gov/smartgrid NIST Smart Grid Homepage] == References == {{reflist|30em}} {{Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers}} [[Category:Smart grid]] [[Category:Renewable energy technology]] [[Category:Emerging technologies]] [[Category:Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers|Smart grid]]

{{chembox | Verifiedfields = changed | Watchedfields = changed | verifiedrevid = 446242167 | Name = Iodine heptafluoride | ImageFile = Iodine-heptafluoride-2D-dimensions.png | ImageName = Structure of the iodine heptafluoride molecule | ImageFileL1 = Iodine-heptafluoride-3D-balls.png | ImageNameL1 = Iodine heptafluoride | ImageFileR1 = Iodine-heptafluoride-3D-vdW.png | ImageNameR1 = Iodine heptafluoride | OtherNames = Iodine(VII) fluoride
Heptafluoroiodine |Section1={{Chembox Identifiers | InChI = 1/F7I/c1-8(2,3,4,5,6)7 | InChIKey = XRURPHMPXJDCOO-UHFFFAOYAO | SMILES = FI(F)(F)(F)(F)(F)F | StdInChI_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChI = 1S/F7I/c1-8(2,3,4,5,6)7 | StdInChIKey_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChIKey = XRURPHMPXJDCOO-UHFFFAOYSA-N | CASNo_Ref = {{cascite|correct|??}} | CASNo = 16921-96-3 | ChemSpiderID_Ref = {{chemspidercite|correct|chemspider}} | ChemSpiderID =21477354 | PubChem = 85645 }} |Section2={{Chembox Properties | Formula = IF7 | Appearance = colorless gas | MolarMass = 259.90 g/mol | Density = 2.6 g/cm3 (6 °C)
2.7 g/cm3 (25 °C) | Solubility = soluble Pradyot Patnaik. ''Handbook of Inorganic Chemicals''. McGraw-Hill, 2002, {{ISBN|0-07-049439-8}} | MeltingPtC = 4.5 | MeltingPt_notes = (triple point) | BoilingPtC = 4.8 | BoilingPt_notes = (sublimes at 1 atm) }} |Section3={{Chembox Related | OtherCompounds = [[iodine pentafluoride]] }} }} '''Iodine heptafluoride''', also known as iodine(VII) fluoride or iodine fluoride, is an [[interhalogen compound]] with the chemical formula [[iodine|I]][[fluoride|F]]7.Macintyre, J. E. (Ed.). (1992). ''Dictionary of Inorganic Compounds'' (Vol. 3). London: Chapman & Hall.O'Neil, Maryadele J. (Ed.). (2001). ''The Merck Index'' (13th ed.). Whitehouse Station, NJ: Merck. It has an unusual [[Pentagonal bipyramid molecular geometry|pentagonal bipyramidal]] structure, as predicted by [[VSEPR theory]].{{cite journal | title = On the problem of heptacoordination: vibrational spectra, structure, and fluxionality of iodine heptafluoride |author1=K. O. Christe |author2=E. C. Curtis |author3=D. A. Dixon | journal = [[Journal of the American Chemical Society]] | year = 1993 | volume = 115 | issue = 4 | pages = 1520–1526 | doi = 10.1021/ja00057a044 }} The molecule can undergo a [[pseudorotation]]al rearrangement called the [[Bartell mechanism]], which is like the [[Berry mechanism]] but for a heptacoordinated system.{{cite journal | title = Structure, Pseudorotation, and Vibrational Mode Coupling in IF7: An Electron Diffraction Study |author1=W. J. Adams |author2=H. Bradford Thompson |author3=L. S. Bartell | journal = [[Journal of Chemical Physics]] | year = 1970 | volume = 53 | issue = 10 | pages = 4040–4046 | doi = 10.1063/1.1673876 }} It forms colourless crystals, which melt at 4.5 °C: the liquid range is extremely narrow, with the boiling point at 4.77 °C. The dense vapor has a mouldy, acrid odour. The molecule has D5h symmetry. ==Preparation== IF7 is prepared by passing [[Fluorine|F2]] through liquid [[Iodine pentafluoride|IF5]] at 90 °C, then heating the vapours to 270 °C. Alternatively, this compound can be prepared from fluorine and dried [[palladium iodide|palladium]] or [[potassium iodide]] to minimize the formation of IOF5, an impurity arising by hydrolysis.{{cite journal| title = Iodine Heptafluoride | first1 = W. C. | last1 = Schumb | first2 = M. A. | last2 = Lynch | journal = [[Industrial & Engineering Chemistry]] | year = 1950 | volume = 42 | issue = 7 | pages = 1383–1386 | doi = 10.1021/ie50487a035 }}{{cite journal| title = "Das Jod-7-fluorid" (The iodine-7-fluoride) | language = German | last1 = Ruff | first1 = O. | last2 = Keim | first2 = R. | journal = [[Zeitschrift für Anorganische und Allgemeine Chemie]] | year = 1930 | volume = 193 | issue = 1/2 | pages = 176–186 | doi = 10.1002/zaac.19301930117 }} Iodine heptafluoride is also produced as a by-product when [[dioxygenyl hexafluoroplatinate]] is used to prepare other platinum(V) compounds such as [[potassium hexafluoroplatinate(V)]], using [[potassium fluoride]] in iodine pentafluoride solution:{{cite book | title = Halogen Chemistry | chapter = Pentahalides of the Transition Metals | pages = 179–226 | volume = 3 | first1 = A. D. | last1 = Beveridge | first2 = H. C. | last2 = Clark | editor-first = Viktor | editor-last = Gutmann | publisher = [[Academic Press]] | year = 1967 | isbn = 9780323148474 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=q0j8Imd8yQsC&pg=PA212}} :2 O2PtF6 + 2 KF + IF5 → 2 KPtF6 + 2 O2 + IF7 ==Safety considerations== IF7 is highly irritating to both the skin and the mucous membranes. It also is a strong oxidizer and can cause fire on contact with organic material. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://webbook.nist.gov/cgi/cbook.cgi?ID=C16921963 WebBook page for IF7] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060116134617/http://www.npi.gov.au/database/substance-info/profiles/44.html National Pollutant Inventory - Fluoride and compounds fact sheet] *[http://www.webelements.com/webelements/compounds/text/I/F7I1-16921963.html web elements listing] {{Iodine compounds}} {{fluorine compounds}} [[Category:Fluorides]] [[Category:Iodine compounds]] [[Category:Interhalogen compounds]] [[Category:Oxidizing agents]] [[Category:Hypervalent molecules]]

{{cleanup|date=August 2018|reason=Recently merged from an article with similar content}} [[File:20_micro_litter_liquid_marble_coated_with_the_Teflon_powder.jpg|thumb|20 μL liquid marble coated with the Teflon powder |right|220px]]
'''Liquid marbles''' are non-stick droplets (normally [[aqueous]]) wrapped by [[micro-]] or [[nano-]]metrically scaled [[hydrophobic]], [[colloidal particle]]s ([[Teflon]], [[polyethylene]], [[lycopodium powder]], [[carbon black]], etc.); representing a platform for a diversity of chemical and biological applications.<ref name=Aussillous2001>{{cite journal|doi=10.1038/35082026|pmid=11418851|title=Liquid marbles|journal=Nature|volume=411|issue=6840|pages=924–7|year=2001|last1=Aussillous|first1=Pascale|last2=Quéré|first2=David}}</ref><ref name=Aussillous2006>{{cite journal|doi=10.1098/rspa.2005.1581 |title=Properties of liquid marbles |journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences |volume=462 |issue=2067 |pages=973 |year=2006 |last1=Quéré |first1=David |last2=Aussillous |first2=Pascale |bibcode=2006RSPSA.462..973A }}</ref><ref name=McHale2015>{{cite journal|doi=10.1039/C5SM00084J |pmid=25723648 |title=Liquid marbles: Topical context within soft matter and recent progress |journal=Soft Matter |volume=11 |issue=13 |pages=2530–46 |year=2015 |last1=McHale |first1=G |last2=Newton |first2=M. I |bibcode=2015SMat...11.2530M }}</ref> Liquid marbles are also found naturally; [[aphid]]s convert honeydew droplets into marbles.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1098/rspb.2002.1999 |pmid=12065036 |pmc=1691028 |title=How aphids lose their marbles |journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences |volume=269 |issue=1497 |pages=1211 |year=2002 |last1=Pike |first1=N |last2=Richard |first2=D |last3=Foster |first3=W |last4=Mahadevan |first4=L }}</ref> A variety of non-organic and organic liquids may be converted into liquid marbles.<ref name=McHale2015/><ref name=Bormashenko2015>{{cite journal |doi=10.1021/acs.jpcc.5b01307|title=Self-Propulsion of Liquid Marbles: Leidenfrost-like Levitation Driven by Marangoni Flow|journal=The Journal of Physical Chemistry C|volume=119|issue=18|pages=9910|year=2015|last1=Bormashenko|first1=Edward|last2=Bormashenko|first2=Yelena|last3=Grynyov|first3=Roman|last4=Aharoni|first4=Hadas|last5=Whyman|first5=Gene|last6=Binks|first6=Bernard P|arxiv=1502.04292}}</ref><ref name=Bormashenko2017>{{cite journal |doi=10.1021/acs.langmuir.6b03231|pmid=28114756|title=Liquid Marbles, Elastic Nonstick Droplets: From Minireactors to Self-Propulsion|journal=Langmuir|volume=33|issue=3|pages=663–669|year=2016|last1=Bormashenko|first1=Edward}}</ref> Liquid marbles demonstrate elastic properties and do not [[Coalescence (physics)|coalesce]] when bounced or pressed lightly.<ref name=Bormashenko2017/> Liquid marbles demonstrate a potential as micro-reactors, micro-containers for growing micro-organisms and [[Cell (biology)|cells]], micro-fluidics devices, and have even been used in [[unconventional computing]].<ref name=Bormashenko2015/><ref name=Bormashenko2017/><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Draper|first=Thomas C.|last2=Fullarton|first2=Claire|last3=Phillips|first3=Neil|last4=Costello|first4=Ben P.J. de Lacy|last5=Adamatzky|first5=Andrew|title=Liquid marble interaction gate for collision-based computing|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1369702117305801|journal=Materials Today|volume=20|issue=10|pages=561–568|doi=10.1016/j.mattod.2017.09.004|year=2017}}</ref> Liquid marbles remain stable on solid and liquid surfaces.<ref name="Aussillous2001" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wong, Cl.Y. H. M. Adda-Bedia M., Vella, D.|date=2017|title=Non-wetting drops at liquid interfaces: from liquid marbles to Leidenfrost drops|url=http://pubs.rsc.org/en/content/articlelanding/2017/sm/c7sm00990a#!divAbstract|journal=Soft Matter|volume=13|issue=31|pages=5250–5260|doi=10.1039/C7SM00990A|pmid=28644495|via=|arxiv=1706.03959|bibcode=2017SMat...13.5250W}}</ref> Statics and dynamics of rolling and bouncing of liquid marbles were reported.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Capillarity and Wetting Phenomena {{!}} SpringerLink|last=de Gennes|first=Pierre-Gilles|last2=Brochard-Wyart|first2=Françoise|last3=Quéré|first3=David|language=en-gb|doi=10.1007/978-0-387-21656-0|year = 2004|isbn = 978-1-4419-1833-8}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Supakar|first=T.|date=2017|title=Impact dynamics of particle-coated droplets|journal=Physical Review E|volume=95|issue=1|pages=013106|doi=10.1103/physreve.95.013106|pmid=28208334|bibcode=2017PhRvE..95a3106S}}</ref> Liquid marbles coated with [[Polydisperse|poly-disperse]]<ref name="Bormashenko2017" /> and [[Monodisperse|mono-disperse]] particles have been reported.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Li|first=Xiaoguang(李晓光 )|last2=Wang|first2=Yiqi(王义琪 )|last3=Huang|first3=Junchao(黄俊超 )|last4=Yang|first4=Yao(杨瑶 )|last5=Wang|first5=Renxian(王仁贤 )|last6=Geng|first6=Xingguo(耿兴国 )|last7=Zang|first7=Duyang(臧渡洋 )|date=2017-12-25|title=Monolayer nanoparticle-covered liquid marbles derived from a sol-gel coating|journal=Applied Physics Letters|volume=111|issue=26|pages=261604|doi=10.1063/1.5010725|issn=0003-6951|bibcode=2017ApPhL.111z1604L}}</ref> Liquid marbles are not hermetically coated by solid particles but connected to the gaseous phase. Kinetics of the [[evaporation]] of liquid marbles has been investigated.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fullarton|first=Claire|last2=Draper|first2=Thomas C.|last3=Phillips|first3=Neil|last4=Mayne|first4=Richard|last5=Costello|first5=Ben P. J. de Lacy|last6=Adamatzky|first6=Andrew|date=2018-02-06|title=Evaporation, Lifetime, and Robustness Studies of Liquid Marbles for Collision-Based Computing|journal=Langmuir|language=EN|volume=34|issue=7|pages=2573–2580|doi=10.1021/acs.langmuir.7b04196|pmid=29359941}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ooi|first=Chin Hong|last2=Bormashenko|first2=Edward|last3=Nguyen|first3=Anh V.|last4=Evans|first4=Geoffrey M.|last5=Dao|first5=Dzung V.|last6=Nguyen|first6=Nam-Trung|date=2016-06-21|title=Evaporation of Ethanol–Water Binary Mixture Sessile Liquid Marbles|journal=Langmuir|volume=32|issue=24|pages=6097–6104|doi=10.1021/acs.langmuir.6b01272|pmid=27230102|issn=0743-7463}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dandan|first=Merve|last2=Erbil|first2=H. Yildirim|date=2009-07-21|title=Evaporation Rate of Graphite Liquid Marbles: Comparison with Water Droplets|journal=Langmuir|volume=25|issue=14|pages=8362–8367|doi=10.1021/la900729d|pmid=19499944|issn=0743-7463}}</ref>
==Interfacial water marbles== Liquid marbles were first reported by P. Aussillous and D. Quere<ref name="Aussillous2001" /> in 2001, who described a new method to construct portable [[Drop (liquid)|water drop]]lets in the atmospheric environment with [[hydrophobic]] coating on their surface to prevent the contact between water and the solid ground (Figure 1). Liquid marbles provide a new approach to transport liquid mass on the solid surface, which sufficiently transform the inconvenient glass containers into flexible, user-specified hydrophobic coating composed of powders of hydrophobic materials. Since then, the applications of liquid marbles in no-loss mass transport, [[microfluidics]] and [[microreactor]]s have been extensively investigated.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Karokine|first1=Nikita|last2=Anyfantakis|first2=Manos|last3=Morel|first3=Mathieu|last4=Rudiuk|first4=Sergii|last5=Bickel|first5=Thomas|last6=Baigl|first6=Damien|title=Light-driven transport of a liquid marble with and against surface flows|journal=Angewandte Chemie International Edition|date=5 September 2016|volume=55|issue=37|pages=11183–11187|doi=10.1002/anie.201603639|pmid=27381297|url=https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-01392406/file/KavokineAC2016_postprint.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Zhao|first1=Yan|last2=Fang|first2=Jian|last3=Wang|first3=Hongxia|last4=Wang|first4=Xungai|last5=Lin|first5=Tong|title=Magnetic liquid marbles: manipulation of liquid droplets using highly hydrophobic Fe3O4 nanoparticles|journal=Advanced Materials|date=9 February 2010|volume=22|issue=6|pages=707–710|doi=10.1002/adma.200902512|pmid=20217774}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Arbatan|first1=Tina|last2=Li|first2=Lizi|last3=Tian|first3=Junfei|last4=Shen|first4=Wei|title=Liquid marbles as micro-bioreactors for rapid blood typing|journal=Advanced Healthcare Materials|date=11 January 2012|volume=1|issue=1|pages=80–83|doi=10.1002/adhm.201100016|pmid=23184689}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Sarvi|first1=Fatemeh|last2=Jain|first2=Kanika|last3=Arbatan|first3=Tina|last4=Verma|first4=Paul J.|last5=Hourigan|first5=Kerry|last6=Thompson|first6=Mark C.|last7=Shen|first7=Wei|last8=Chan|first8=Peggy P.Y.|title=Cardiogenesis of embryonic stem cells with liquid marble micro-bioreactor|journal=Advanced Healthcare Materials|date=7 January 2015|volume=4|issue=1|pages=77–86|doi=10.1002/adhm.201400138|pmid=24818841}}</ref> However, [[liquid marbles]] only reflect the water behavior at the solid-air interface, while there is no report on the water behavior at the liquid-liquid interface, as a result of the so-called coalescence cascade phenomenon. [[File:Liquid_marble_on_glass_slide.png|thumb|Figure 1. A liquid marble sitting on the glass slide.]] When a water droplet is in contact with a water reservoir, it will quickly pinch off from the reservoir and form a smaller daughter droplet, while this daughter droplet will continue to go through a similar contact-pinch off-splitting process until completed [[Coalescence (physics)|coalescence]] into the reservoir, the combination or summary of these self-similar coalescence processes is called coalescence cascade.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Blanchette|first1=François|last2=Bigioni|first2=Terry P.|title=Partial coalescence of drops at liquid interfaces|journal=Nature Physics|date=1 April 2006|volume=2|issue=4|pages=254–257|doi=10.1038/nphys268|bibcode=2006NatPh...2..254B}}</ref> The underlying mechanism of coalescence cascade has been studied in detail but there has been mere attempt to control and make use of it.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Thoroddsen|first1=S. T.|last2=Takehara|first2=K.|title=The coalescence cascade of a drop|journal=Physics of Fluids|date=June 2000|volume=12|issue=6|pages=1265–1267|doi=10.1063/1.870380|bibcode=2000PhFl...12.1265T}} </ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Klyuzhin|first1=Ivan S.|last2=Lenna|first2=Federico|last3=Roeder|first3=Brandon|last4=Wexler|first4=Adam|last5=Pollack|first5=Gerald H|title=Persisting water droplets on water surfaces|journal=Journal of Physical Chemistry B|date=11 November 2010|volume=114|issue=44|pages=14020–14027|doi=10.1021/jp106899k|pmid=20961076|pmc=3208511}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Geri|first1=Michela|last2=Keshavarz|first2=Bavand|last3=McKinley|first3=Gareth H.|last4=Bush|first4=John W. M.|title=Thermal delay of drop coalescence|journal=Journal of Fluid Mechanics|date=25 December 2017|volume=833|pages=R3|doi=10.1017/jfm.2017.686|bibcode=2017JFM...833R...3G}}</ref>. Until recently, Liu et al. has filled this void by proposing a new method to control coalescence cascade by using nanostructured coating at the liquid-liquid interface, —the interfacial liquid marbles.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Liu|first1=Yang|last2=Zhang|first2=Xinyu|last3=Poyraz|first3=Selcuk|last4=Zhang|first4=Chao|last5=Xin|first5=John|title=One-step synthesis of multifunctional zinc-iron-oxide hybrid carbon nanowires by chemical fusion for supercapacitors and interfacial water marbles|journal=ChemNanoMat|volume=4|issue=6|pages=546–556|date=15 March 2018|doi=10.1002/cnma.201800075|hdl=10397/78424}}</ref> [[File:Interfacial_liquid_marble.png|thumb|Figure 2. An interfacial water marble sitting on the hexane-water interface.]] Similar to liquid marbles at the solid-air interface, the interfacial liquid marbles are constructed on the [[hexane]]/[[water]] interface using water droplets with a surface coating composed of [[Nanoscopic scale|nanoscale]] materials with special [[Wetting|wettability]] (Figure 2). To realize interfacial water marbles at hexane/water interface, the individual particle size of the surface coating layer should be as small as possible, so that the contact line between the particles and the water reservoir can be minimized; special wettability with mixed [[hydrophobicity]] and [[hydrophilicity]] is also preferred for the interfacial water marble formation. The interfacial water marble can be fabricated by firstly coating a water droplet with [[nanomaterials]] with special wettability, e.g. hybrid carbon nanowires, [[Graphite oxide|graphene oxide]]. Afterwards a secondary coating layer of [[polyvinylidene fluoride]] (PVDF) is applied onto the coated water droplet. The doubly-coated water droplet is then cast into the hexane/water mixture and eventually settled at the hexane/water interface to form the interfacial water marble. During this process, the PVDF coating quickly diffused into hexane to balance the hydrophobic interaction between hexane and the water droplet, while the nanomaterials quickly self-assembled into a nanostructured protective layer on the droplet surface through the [[Marangoni effect]].
The interfacial water marble can completely resist [[Coalescence (physics)|coalescence]] cascade and exist nearly permanently at the hexane/water interface, providing that the hexane phase is not depleted by [[vaporization]]. The interfacial water marbles can also realize a series of stimuli-responsive motions by integrating the functional materials into the surface coating layer. Due to their uniqueness in both form and behavior, the interfacial water marbles are speculated to have remarkable applications in [[microfluidics]], [[Microreactor|microreactors]] and mass-transport.
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
[[Image:Micrometeorite.jpg|thumb|250px|Micrometeorite, collected from the Antarctic snow, was a micrometeoroid before it entered the Earth's atmosphere]] A '''micrometeoroid''' is a tiny [[meteoroid]]; a small particle of rock in space, usually weighing less than a [[gram]]. A [[micrometeorite]] is such a particle that survives passage through the [[Atmosphere of Earth|Earth's atmosphere]] and reaches the Earth's surface.
== Scientific interest == {{see also|Cosmic dust}}
Micrometeoroids are very small pieces of rock or metal broken off from larger chunks of rock and debris often dating back to the birth of the [[Solar System]]. Micrometeoroids are extremely common in space. Tiny particles are a major contributor to [[space weathering]] processes. When they hit the surface of the [[Moon]], or any airless body ([[Mercury (planet)|Mercury]], the [[asteroid]]s, etc.), the resulting melting and vaporization causes darkening and other optical changes in the [[regolith]]. In order to understand the micrometeoroid population better, a number of spacecraft (including [[Lunar Orbiter 1]], [[Luna 3]], [[Mars 1]] and [[Pioneer 5]]) have carried micrometeoroid detectors.
In 1957 Hans Peterson conducted one of the first direct measurements of the fall of space dust on the [[Earth]], estimating it to be 14,300,000 tons per year.<ref>Pettersson, Hans. "Cosmic Spherules and Meteoritic Dust." ''Scientific American'', Volume 202 Issue 2, February 1960, pp. 123–132.</ref> If this were true, then the Moon would be covered to a very great depth as there are limited forms of erosion to remove this material. In 1961 [[Arthur C. Clarke]] popularized this possibility in his novel ''[[A Fall of Moondust]]''. This was cause for some concern among the groups attempting to land on the Moon, so a series of new studies followed to better characterize the issue. This included the launch of several spacecraft designed to directly measure the micrometeorite flux ([[Pegasus satellite program]]) or directly measure the dust on the surface of the Moon ([[Surveyor Program]]). These showed that the flux was much lower than earlier estimates, around 10,000 to 20,000 tons per year, and that the surface of the Moon is relatively rocky.<ref>Snelling, Andrew and David Rush. [http://static.icr.org/i/pdf/technical/Moon-Dust-and-the-Age-of-the-Solar-System.pdf "Moon Dust and the Age of the Solar System."] ''Creation Ex-Nihilo Technical Journal'', Volume 7, Number 1, 1993, p. 242.</ref> Most lunar samples returned during the [[Apollo Program]] have micrometeorite impacts marks, typically called "zap pits", on their upper surfaces.<ref>{{Citation | last = Wilhelms | first = Don E. | title = To a Rocky Moon: A Geologist's History of Lunar Exploration | publisher = [[University of Arizona Press]] | page = 97 | url = http://www.lpi.usra.edu/publications/books/rockyMoon/06Chapter5.pdf | isbn = 978-0816510658 }}</ref> [[File:Lunar sample 61195 S72-37972.jpg|thumb|right|240px|Lunar sample 61195 from [[Apollo 16]] shows numerous zap pits on its surface caused by micrometeorite impacts]]
Micrometeoroids have less stable [[orbit]]s than meteoroids, due to their greater [[surface area]] to [[mass]] ratio. Micrometeoroids that fall to Earth can provide information on millimeter scale heating events in the [[solar nebula]]. [[Meteorites]] and [[micrometeorites]] (as they are known upon arrival at the Earth's surface) can only be collected in areas where there is no terrestrial [[sedimentation]], typically polar regions. Ice is collected and then melted and filtered so the micrometeorites can be extracted under a microscope.
Sufficiently small micrometeoroids avoid significant heating on entry into the [[Earth's atmosphere]].<ref>P. Fraundorf (1980) The distribution of temperature maxima for micrometeorites decelerated in the Earth's atmosphere without melting ''Geophys. Res. Lett.'' '''10''':765-768.</ref> Collection of such particles by high flying aircraft began in the 1970s,<ref>D. E. Brownlee, D. A. Tomandl and E. Olszewski (1977) Interplanetary dust: A new source of extraterrestrial material for laboratory studies, ''Proc. Lunar Sci. Conf. '''8th''':149-160.</ref> since which time these samples of stratosphere-collected [[Interplanetary dust cloud#Collecting interplanetary dust on earth|interplanetary dust]] (called ''Brownlee particles'' before their extraterrestrial origin was confirmed) have become an important component of the [[extraterrestrial materials]] available for study in laboratories on Earth.
==Effect on spacecraft operations== {{see also|Space debris}} [[File:SMM panel hole.jpg|thumb|Electron micrograph image of an orbital debris hole made in the panel of the [[Solar Maximum Mission|Solar Max]] satellite.]] Micrometeoroids pose a significant threat to [[space exploration]]. The average velocity of micrometeoroids relative to a [[spacecraft]] in orbit is 10 kilometers per second (22,500 mph). Resistance to micrometeoroid impact is a significant design challenge for spacecraft and [[space suit]] designers (''See [[Thermal Micrometeoroid Garment]]''). While the tiny sizes of most micrometeoroids limits the damage incurred, the high velocity impacts will constantly degrade the outer casing of spacecraft in a manner analogous to [[sandblasting]]. Long term exposure can threaten the functionality of spacecraft systems.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nasa.gov/centers/wstf/laboratories/hypervelocity/mmod.html|title=Micrometeoroids and Orbital Debris (MMOD)|last=Rodriguez|first=Karen|date=April 26, 2010|website=www.nasa.gov|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-18}}</ref>
Impacts by small objects with extremely high velocity (10 kilometers per second) are a current area of research in [[terminal ballistics]]. (Accelerating objects up to such velocities is difficult; current techniques include [[linear motor]]s and [[shaped charge]]s.) The risk is especially high for objects in space for long periods of time, such as [[satellites]].<ref name=":0" /> They also pose major engineering challenges in theoretical low-cost lift systems such as [[Tether propulsion|rotovators]], [[space elevator]]s, and orbital airships.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Space Elevators: An Assessment of the Technological Feasibility and the Way Forward|last = Swan, Raitt, Swan, Penny, Knapman|first = Peter A., David I., Cathy W., Robert E., John M.|publisher = International Academy of Astronautics|year = 2013|isbn = 9782917761311|location = Virginia, USA|pages = 10–11, 207–208}}</ref><ref>Swan, P., Penny, R. Swan, C. Space Elevator Survivability, Space Debris Mitigation, Lulu.com Publishers, 2011</ref>
==Footnotes== {{reflist}}
==See also== * [[Extraterrestrial materials]] * [[Interplanetary dust cloud]]
==External links== * [http://www.psrd.hawaii.edu/Sept07/cosmicSpherules.html Melted Crumbs from Asteroid Vesta] article about micrometeorites collected in Antarctica in Planetary Science Research Discoveries educational journal
{{meteorites}}
