{{Refimprove|date=October 2018}} [[File:Hybrid Power System.gif|thumb|upright=1.2|A hybrid wind and solar power system]]
'''Wind hybrid power systems''' combines [[wind turbine]]s with other storage and/or generation sources. One of the key issues with [[wind energy]] is its [[Intermittent power source|intermittent nature]]. This has led to numerous methods of storing energy. == Wind-hydro system == A wind-hydro system generates [[electric energy]] combining wind turbines and [[pumped storage]]. The combination has been the subject of long-term discussion, and an experimental plant, which also tested wind turbines, was implemented by [[Nova Scotia Power]] at its [[Wreck Cove]] hydro electric power site in the late 1970s, but was decommissioned within ten years. Since, no other system has been implemented at a single location as of late 2010.<ref name=ieee>{{cite web|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/freeabs_all.jsp?arnumber=5512672|publisher=[[IEEE]]|title=A Wind-Hydro-Pumped Storage Station Leading to High RES Penetration in the Autonomous Island System of Ikaria|accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref>
Wind-hydro stations dedicate all, or a significant portion, of their wind power resources to pumping water into pumped storage reservoirs. These reservoirs are an implementation of [[grid energy storage]].
=== Advantages === Wind and its generation potential is inherently variable. However, when this energy source is used to pump water into reservoirs at an elevation (the principle behind pumped storage), the potential energy of the water is relatively stable and can be used to generate electrical power by releasing it into a [[hydropower]] plant when needed.<ref name=ie2>{{cite web|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/freeabs_all.jsp?arnumber=4494596|publisher=[[IEEE]]|date=22 April 2008|title=Stochastic Joint Optimization of Wind Generation and Pumped-Storage Units in an Electricity Market|accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref> The combination has been described as particularly suited to islands that are not connected to larger grids.<ref name=ieee/>
===Proposals=== During the 1980s, an installation was proposed in the Netherlands.<ref name="Corporation1983">{{cite book|author=Bonnier Corporation|title=Popular Science|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qq6GBPoHQpAC&pg=PA85|accessdate=17 April 2011|date=April 1983|publisher=Bonnier Corporation|pages=85, 86|issn=0161-7370}}</ref> The [[IJsselmeer]] would be used as the reservoir, with wind turbines located on its dike.<ref name="Hau2006">{{cite book|author=Erich Hau|title=Wind turbines: fundamentals, technologies, application, economics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z4bhObd65IAC&pg=PA568|accessdate=17 April 2011|year=2006|publisher=Birkhäuser|isbn=978-3-540-24240-6|pages=568, 569}}</ref> Feasibility studies have been conducted for installations on the island of [[Ramea]] ([[Newfoundland and Labrador]]) and on the [[Lower Brule Indian Reservation]] ([[South Dakota]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mun.ca/harriscentre/reports/arf/2009/ARF_Iqbal_RameaHybrid.pdf|publisher=[[Memorial University of Newfoundland]]|title=Feasibility Study of Pumped Hydro Energy Storage for Ramea Wind-Diesel Hybrid Power System|accessdate=2011-04-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://apps1.eere.energy.gov/tribalenergy/pdfs/lowerbrule03final.pdf|title=Final Report: Lower Brule Sioux Tribe Wind-Pumped Storage Feasibility Study Project|publisher=United States Department of Energy|accessdate=2011-04-17}}</ref>
An installation at [[Ikaria Island]], Greece, had entered the construction phase as of 2010.<ref name=ieee/>
The island of [[El Hierro]] is where the first world's first wind-hydro power station is expected to be complete.<ref>{{cite news|title=El Hierro, an island in the wind|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2011/apr/19/canary-island-renewable-energy-lehir|accessdate=25 April 2011|newspaper=Guardian|date=19 April 2011}}</ref> [[Current TV]] called this "a blueprint for a sustainable future on planet Earth". It was designed to cover between 80-100% of the island's power and was set to be operational in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/arts-culture/a-blueprint-for-green|title=A blueprint for green|website=Thenational.ae|accessdate=29 October 2018}}</ref> However, these expectations were not realized in practice, probably due to inadequate reservoir volume and persistent problems with grid stability.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://euanmearns.com/an-independent-evaluation-of-the-el-hierro-wind-pumped-hydro-system/|title=An Independent Evaluation of the El Hierro Wind & Pumped Hydro System|date=23 February 2017|website=Euanmearns.com|accessdate=29 October 2018}}</ref>
100% renewable energy systems require an over-capacity of wind or solar power.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2017/01/170125120742.htm|title=100% renewable energy sources require overcapacity: To switch electricity supply from nuclear to wind and solar power is not so simple|work=ScienceDaily|access-date=2017-09-15|language=en}}</ref>
== Wind-hydrogen system == [[File:Wind hydrogen.JPG|450px|frameless|left]]
One method of storing wind energy is the [[Hydrogen production|production of hydrogen]] through the [[electrolysis]] of [[water]]. This [[hydrogen]] is subsequently used to generate electricity during periods when demand can not be matched by wind alone. The energy in the [[Hydrogen storage|stored hydrogen]] can be converted into electrical power through [[fuel cell]] technology or a [[Internal combustion engine#Hydrogen engine|combustion engine]] linked to an [[electrical generator]].
Successfully [[Hydrogen storage|storing hydrogen]] has many issues which need to be overcome, such as [[Hydrogen embrittlement|embrittlement]] of the materials used in the power system.
This technology is being developed in many countries and has even seen a recent [[Initial Public Offering|IPO]] of an Australian firm called Wind Hydrogen that looks to commercialise this technology in both Australia and the UK.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whlenergy.com/ |title="WHL Energy Limited (WHL)" is an Australian publicly listed company focused on developing and commercializing energy assets including wind energy, solar, biomass and clean fossil fuels|website=Whlenergy.com|accessdate=4 July 2010}}</ref> Essentially Wind Hydrogen offers a source of domestic and vehicular energy for rural communities where current [[Electric power transmission|energy transmission]] costs are prohibitive. Test sites include:
{| class="wikitable floatleft" |- ! Community ! Country ! Wind MW |- | [[Ramea, Newfoundland and Labrador]]<ref>[http://www.acoa.ca/e/media/press/press.shtml?3738 "Remote Community Wind-Hydrogen-Diesel Energy Solution"] Renew ND. Retrieved 30 October 2007.</ref> | [[Newfoundland and Labrador|Newfoundland, Canada]] |0.3 |- | Prince Edward Island Wind-Hydrogen Village<ref>[http://www.gov.pe.ca/envengfor/index.php3?number=1007450&lang=E "Prince Edward Island Wind-Hydrogen Village"] Renew ND. Retrieved 30 October 2007.</ref> | [[Prince Edward Island|PEI, Canada]] | |- | [[Lolland]]<ref>[http://www.renewableenergyaccess.com/rea/news/story?id=48873 "First Danish Hydrogen Energy Plant Is Operational"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926231034/http://www.renewableenergyaccess.com/rea/news/story?id=48873# |date=26 September 2007 }} Renew ND. Retrieved 30 October 2007.</ref> | [[Region Sjælland|Denmark]] | |- | [[Bismarck, North Dakota|Bismarck]]<ref>[http://www.areavoices.com/renewnd/?blog=10613 "North Dakota has first wind-to-hydrogen plant in nation"] Renew ND. Retrieved 27 October 2007.</ref> | [[North Dakota|North Dakota, US]] | |- | Koluel Kaike<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20081006065548/http://www.wbcsd.org/plugins/DocSearch/details.asp?type=DocDet&ObjectId=14610 "Clean Patagonian Energy from Wind and Hydrogen"] Renew ND. Retrieved 30 October 2007</ref> | [[Santa Cruz Province (Argentina)|Santa Cruz, Argentina]] | |- | Ladymoor Renewable Energy Project (LREP)<ref>[http://www.wind-hydrogen.com/Citrus%20(Windfarm%208pp%20A5).pdf "Proposals for Ladymoor Renewable Energy Project"] Renew ND. Retrieved 2 November 2007 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718053333/http://www.wind-hydrogen.com/Citrus%20(Windfarm%208pp%20A5).pdf |date=18 July 2011 }}</ref> | Scotland | |- | Hunterston Hydrogen Project | Scotland | |- | RES2H2<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20060517153440/http://www.infotools.hfpeurope.org/demoactive/greece/demos/proj001.html "RES2H2 - Integration of Renewable Energy Sources with the Hydrogen Vector"] Renew ND. Retrieved 30 October 2007.</ref> | [[Greece]] | 0.50 |- |[[Unst]]<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20071025060018/http://www.sref.co.uk/whats.php "Promoting Unst Renewable Energy (PURE) Project Update"] Renew ND. Retrieved 30 October 2007.</ref> |Scotland | 0.03 |- | [[Utsira]]<ref>[http://www.azom.com/details.asp?newsID=4445 "Hydro Continues Utsira Project"]{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Renew ND. Retrieved 30 October 2007.</ref> | Norway | 0.60 |} {{clear}}
== Wind-diesel system == [[File:Ramea Wind diesel Aug 2007.JPG|thumbnail|right|upright=1.8|Wind Diesel system on [[Ramea, Newfoundland and Labrador|Ramea]] in Canada]]
A wind-diesel hybrid power system combines [[diesel generator]]s and wind turbines,<ref name="Wales AK">[http://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy02osti/31755.pdf Wales, Alaska High-Penetration Wind-Diesel Hybrid Power System] National Renewable Energy Laboratory</ref> usually alongside ancillary equipment such as energy storage, power converters, and various control components, to generate electricity. They are designed to increase capacity and reduce the cost and environmental impact of electrical generation in remote communities and facilities that are not linked to a [[power grid]].<ref name="Wales AK"/> Wind-diesel hybrid systems reduce reliance on diesel fuel, which creates pollution and is costly to transport.<ref name="Wales AK"/>
=== History === Wind-diesel generating systems have been under development and trialled in a number of locations during the latter part of the 20th century. A growing number of viable sites have been developed with increased reliability and minimized technical support costs in remote communities.
=== Technology === The successful integration of wind energy with diesel generating sets relies on complex controls to ensure correct sharing of intermittent wind energy and controllable diesel generation to meet the demand of the usually variable load. The common measure of performance for wind diesel systems is Wind Penetration which is the ratio between Wind Power and Total Power delivered, e.g. 60% wind penetration implies that 60% of the system power comes from the wind. Wind Penetration figures can be either peak or long term. Sites such as [[Mawson Station]], Antarctica, as well as [[Coral Bay, Western Australia|Coral Bay]] and [[Bremer Bay]] in Australia have peak wind penetrations of around 90%. Technical solutions to the varying wind output include controlling wind output using variable speed wind turbines (e.g. [[Enercon]], [[Denham, Western Australia]]), controlling demand such as the heating load (e.g. Mawson), [[Flywheel energy storage|storing energy in a flywheel]] (e.g. Powercorp, Coral Bay). Some installations are now being converted to [[Wind-Hydrogen Hybrid Power Systems|wind hydrogen]] systems such as on [[Ramea]] in Canada which is due for completion in 2010.
=== Communities using wind-diesel hybrids === The following is a, probably incomplete, list of isolated communities utilizing commercial Wind-Diesel hybrid systems with a significant proportion of the energy being derived from wind.
{| class="wikitable" style="width: 80%; font-size: 0.9em; margin: 10px auto 1px auto;" |- ! width=150 |Community ! Country ! Diesel (in MW) ! Wind (in MW) ! Population ! Date Commissioned ! Wind Penetration (peak) ! === Wind-diesel hybrids at mining sites === Recently, in Northern Canada wind-diesel hybrid power systems were built by the mining industry. In remote locations at Lac de Gras, in Canada's Northwest Territories, and Katinniq, Ungava Peninsula, Nunavik, two systems are used to save fuel at mines. There is another system in Argentina.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.th-energy.net/english/platform-renewable-energy-and-mining/database-solar-wind-power-plants/ |title=Database: Solar & wind systems in the mining industry ...|website=Th-Energy.net |access-date=12 May 2015}}</ref>
== Wind-compressed air systems == At power stations that use [[compressed air energy storage]] (CAES), electrical energy is used to compress air and store it in underground facilities such as caverns or abandoned mines. During later periods of high electrical demand, the air is released to power turbines, generally using supplemental [[natural gas]].<ref name=wired>{{cite web|title=Bottled Wind Could Be as Constant as Coal|url=https://www.wired.com/wiredscience/2010/03/compressed-air-plants/|date=March 9, 2010|accessdate=2011-07-15|work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]}}</ref> Power stations that make significant use of CAES are operational in [[McIntosh, Alabama]], Germany, and Japan.<ref name=aog>{{cite book|author1=Sio-Iong Ao|author2=Len Gelman|title=Electrical Engineering and Applied Computing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FI0JNXJ3R4EC&pg=PA41|accessdate=15 July 2011|date=29 June 2011|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-94-007-1191-4|page=41}}</ref> System disadvantages include some energy losses in the CAES process; also, the need for supplemental use of fossil fuels such as natural gas means that these systems do not completely make use of renewable energy.<ref name=boise>{{cite web|title=Overview of Compressed Air Energy Storage|publisher=[[Boise State University]]|url=http://coen.boisestate.edu/WindEnergy/resources/ER-07-001.pdf|accessdate=2011-07-15|page=2}}</ref>
The [[Iowa Stored Energy Park]], projected to begin commercial operation in 2015, will use wind farms in [[Iowa]] as an energy source in conjunction with CAES.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.isepa.com/FAQs.asp#7|title=Frequently Asked Questions|publisher=Iowa Stored Energy Project|accessdate=2011-07-15}}</ref>
== Wind-solar systems == [[File:Eole et Helios.jpg|thumb|150px|Horizontal axis wind-turbine, combined with a solar panel on a lighting pylon at [[Weihai]], [[Shandong]] province, China]]
{{See also|Solar hybrid power systems}}
=== Wind-solar building === The [[Pearl River Tower]] in [[Guangzhou]], China, will mix solar panel on its windows and several wind turbines at different stories of its structure, allowing this tower to be energy positive.
=== Wind-solar lighting === In several parts of China & India, there are lighting pylons with combinations of solar panels and wind-turbines at their top. This allows space already used for lighting to be used more efficiently with two complementary energy productions units. Most common models use horizontal axis wind-turbines, but now models are appearing with vertical axis wind-turbines, using a helicoidal shaped, twisted-[[Savonius]] system.
